commentBody:
No theme. Not worth doing. 

0/10. 

Looks like it's the archive today.
Unusual to have a themeless for Sunday, but a fun challenge. Anyone else think the face looks like the rabbit from Trix?
Meh

Always a letdown to see that the Sunday puzzle you've started unexpectedly has no theme.  Why bother with a title then?  Why not just "Unthemed #(whatever)"?

A lot of proper names are going to give people problems, and several of them cross:  LARTER/DELANEY, REEM/ROSAMUND, and SAEED crossing a TYPE O which is difficult to guess if you go with the usual term for the 38A instrument, POTTER's WHEEL.  

I figured it all out eventually, but I can see how others would have had trouble with any of those.  

And I didn't get much enjoyment out of it.  An oversized themeless is a slog.

Rafael Musa said that although he wasn't a stunt constructor, this was a stunt puzzle (fewest entries in a Sunday grid).

It wasn't worth it.  I almost agree with George, much to my horror.
Rabbit rabbit.

I usually enjoy Rafa's creations, and while this puzzle was fresh, I'd prefer not to be served a large themeless Tuesday as a Sunday.

The only "challenge" for me was realizing the 28A WHEELS were not for POTTERs but for their POTTERY. 

I found exactly two clever clues: 37A and 31D.

Lots of people today, most of whom crossed non-people. I hope most people who don't know people will be able to handle the 62Ax43D people cross and 96Ax87D+68D!
I'd hate to see anyone stuck in Natick. Or Lodi.

I'm sure it was hard to construct...

Mini:
I am confident the constructor did not need to consult Google to come up with the 1A clue and answer.

I love theme-less puzzles. Saturday's was great. Usually Sunday themes make the puzzle pretty easy to solve; for me, they tend to take longer than Saturdays due to the size, not the difficulty. However, I blew through this one, 13 minutes faster than my Sunday average. Having the fewest entries in a Sunday puzzle should have made it challenging, but it didn't. I think it's the clueing. They're fairly straightforward, like a typical Sunday, except the straightforward clues for themed Sundays are supposed to help you deduce the theme. Obviously, that's not necessary here. When I finished this puzzle, I didn't have the feeling of accomplishment I get from a Saturday, nor did I get to appreciate a clever Sunday theme. This one might go down in the record books but wasn't particularly challenging or fun.

I really wanted 31D to be FUtureslob.  Like, I really, really wanted that...  Alas, 'twas not to be. 

Fine enough puzzle, I guess, but I really looked forward to a fun theme, so that's pretty disappointing. What looked like a jack 'o lantern grid, or maybe a bunny rabbit, furthered my enthusiasm for what the theme would be. Alas, also 'twas not to be.  

I did finish significantly faster than my average‚Äîand about three billion times faster‚Äîthan I finished the Saturday puzzle.   

Ah well!  Forward ho!

I‚Äôm surprised by the negativity‚Ä¶I enjoyed watching this giant themeless unfurl (didn‚Äôt love REMATE and EMEET, which I acknowledge are things but awkward nonetheless). Themes are great but so are themeless acrobatics imho. 
As for proper nouns, I always figure it‚Äôs my fault if I don‚Äôt know significant personages.

17 minutes. And I finished in time for Game 7. That's what matters, right?

Speaking of sports, kind of forget to shout out to ELISE Mertens yesterday with all the drama. Not a name I'd have expected to see in a crossword, but it was an easy gimme. I've met her a few times, and, while her singles career never materialized at the highest level, she's been having quite a good doubles career

For me, this is just a giant Sunday sized Saturday puzzle.  I needed thirty five cheats.  I know so many others will just love the crossing of obscure names, obfuscating clues and the like.  But not me!  I did manage to keep my streak, after checking and double checking and getting spouse to find what was keeping the music away.  Alas, I had "Lartar"  crossing "Delanay"!  Whew!

Tomorrow is another day, with a much gentler puzzle waiting.

This went shockingly quickly for such an initially intimidating grid.  Smooth as silk.  I didn't love every clue and it wasn't a laugh riot but it was an honest puzzle with almost no filler.  PSA and ERs and Sty were about it.  Went very quickly for me with basically zero snags.

Nicely done.  Thanks and congratulations on the record, I guess.  :)
Spectacular puzzle and a very satisfying solve. But I‚Äôm shocked to learn that FORTEPIANO is a debut.

I demand a REMATE!  My post with some funny scenarios involving remates got stuck in the filter.
I guess you‚Äôll just have to see if it shows up later.  I don‚Äôt like putting a thing in twice.
Super natick 86D 97A. Never thrilling to see those crossing proper names‚Ä¶. Otherwise a fun solve.

No complaints from me, just a fine puzzle that went down smoothly. Yeah, a bit of a Natick in the southwest, but my first guess was an M and that completed the puzzle. Then I paused and scratched my head at the theme, rechecked the title, and came here to confirm that it was themeless. Yep, OK, I didn't miss anything, all good.

"There's no resisting..."

And almost no resistance

From this large Monday
enoughhhhhh with the names!!!
I was almost certain that a person idolized by a niche audience was going to be some sort of saint (someone who would have a statue or icon in a literal niche) but that wasn't the case.

Regarding the natick in the SW corner ‚Äî I feel that the editors should not allow crossed proper names as a general rule. This is the Sunday version of the NYT crossword, the cr√®me de la cr√®me. I feel like the standards should be a bit higher. I respect anyone that can create a crossword, and I do not mean to take a shot at the constructor, but I do feel like, perhaps, the editors should step in at times.

I admit that I really don‚Äôt know anything about what the editors actually do.
My Diary of a Crossword Fiend review: https://crosswordfiend.com/2025/11/01/sunday-november-2-2025/

Great puzzle! Needed help with the names (as almost always) but was able to get the rest. Took TOO much time trying to find my typo. Sheesh. Lots of fun. I loved the span entries. It makes me happy when I can get many of them without help. Thanks, Rafael. This was just a joy. All y‚Äôall have a great Sunday!

Maybe we have been spoiled with lots of themed Sundays (I can barely remember the last themeless Sunday) but I think making a big smiling bear face grid art and then no theme is kind of mean. Like opening the bag of dog treats and then not giving the pup one. I was like the pup, hopefully nosing all around the whole puzzle hoping to find a revealer hidden in the couch cushions. Nothing üòû
It‚Äôs arguable that TECHNOCRATS are really ‚ÄúOnes skilled in governance.‚Äù
Kind of resent the answer to eccentric.Batty is offensive.

On that SW corner. My first thought was Natick, go for a lookup. But then I had ROS_ _ _ND from crosses.  A few years of doing this xword tells me that [sch.] almost always signals a U, for university, in the initialism. So now ROS_ _UND. Even allowing for weird first name spellings  AM seemed the most appropriate
The obvious answer to 24 across is "trumpism", but it doesn't fit.

So I enjoyed this a lot, I‚Äôm also surprised from the negativity‚Äîapart from being unhappy about not getting a theme on Sunday, which I do understand. I thought the face was supposed to be a pumpkin, and I took one look at the grid and knew it was a themeless (come on, you can‚Äôt make a themeless with this few words, or if you do you‚Äôre even a bigger genius than I can imagine.) So I wasn‚Äôt disappointed trying to find one.
I thought this was Friday level for me, or what I might imagine a Thursday themeless to be. It‚Äôs not that I didn‚Äôt know must of the clues, but it just seemed like I guessed wrong or was misdirected on many of them, or they were on the tip of my tongue and I just couldn‚Äôt get there. I had to jump around all over the place. This was exemplified by ‚ÄúEccentric‚Äù‚ÄîDOTTY? NUTTY? Oh, BATTY. Seems like that was my experience the whole time. Yes, you are right Barry there weren‚Äôt a lot of clever punny clues, but they were clever in other ways that they weren‚Äôt obvious to me and I had to stretch. I had the same Naticks as everyone but it seemed like at least one of the names was guessable.
So I was impressed even if others weren‚Äôt and I had a good time for a Sunday themeless. Oh, thanks for the shout out to RICHARD Feynman‚ÄîI know there are a lot of RICHARD options, but the man was a genius both as a physicist and a teacher, and if you don‚Äôt know him please take the opportunity to learn about him.

What a slog!! A clear testament to a puzzle that has bragging rights for the constructor but no joy for the solvers. Too many proper nouns and obsure clues for a Sunday sized gird making it a total grind‚Ä¶

Not fun. 

Way too many unknown (to me) names. 

No theme?  I feel cheated and disappointed.
This was beautiful and I felt as if I was on the same wavelength. Thanks!

I got stuck in the SW.  I haven‚Äôt heard of REEM Kassis or ROSAMUND Lipton, and as a Canadian I always have trouble with US college sports teams. I had to look up the Nittany Lions.  After that it all fell into place.

First I want to say that the nitrite film that was extremely flammable hasn't been used in decades.  Big plot point in Cinema Paradiso.

This was a fun tough puzzle for me.  A lot of two word figure-outable answers like SUN RIPENING.  You know you have good clues when you stare at it for ten minutes then immediately realize it meant something a little different than you expected.  Like I had PLEA DEALS for a long time then the region fell into place when I realized ARMS DEALS.

A few Naticky squares at the end.  Like I had GRAND PIANO for a while before figuring out FORTE PIANO purely from crossing clues, who the heck has ever heard of a FORTE PIANO?  And some obscure proper names like ROSAMUND and COMANECI.

I don't look up answers I don't know but if I'm 80% sure I'll look it up to confirm and I did that quite a few times today.

I liked this puzzle. Although I enjoy a really clever theme, I often find even a tricky theme makes solving easier and quicker and then I'm sad it's over so fast. Even themeless, this was a fairly smooth solve for me that wound up being 15 minutes quicker than my Sunday average. I had to leave 55A (Girder whose name assumes a serif font) and 71D (Shell competitor) to the end and play around until I found letters that looked right to me. Despite the high number of proper names, I am proud to say I either knew them or work them out on my own.
I kept looking for a theme, but I guess there isn't one. I'm just happy to have solved in a better than average time.
Weather in Antarctica, ending in D and it's NOT cold?

Found this good fun :) 

Of course everyone is free to express their opinion, but I‚Äôm always a bit disappointed when a large number of the comments here are negative. I‚Äôm thankful we have clever people like Mr. Musa to provide puzzles for this fun little hobby of ours.

There were a number of names in this puzzle that were  not familiar to me, and that added a level of difficulty that was otherwise missing.  It didn‚Äôt help that the one name I recognized I misspelled In two spots.

I did like the clue for ARMSDEALS, and the EAI string in STATEAIDED.

TIL that there‚Äôs a difference between a FORTEPIANO and a pianoforte, having only previously heard of the latter.  I love Beethoven piano sonatas as played on the piano.  I‚Äôll have to see if I can find some recordings on the more period appropriate instrument for comparison‚Äôs sake, although a little research shows that he wrote for many of the evolving versions of his favorite instrument.

U ppl must be really smart because I cant figure this puzzle out at all. I really just started doing these crosswords recently so I‚Äôm a beginner‚Ä¶ my excuse. I feel like these involve a lot of previously required knowledge and I am being a made aware of that every day after Monday and Tuesday. ü§£

Marshall Walthew:


By the time I saw your question about whether we liked the Springsteen biopic, the comments section for that day was closed.

So here's what I posted on Facebook:

Les  and I saw ‚ÄúSpringsteen: Deliver Me From Nowhere‚Äù on Tuesday. Having been avid Springsteen fans for decades, we were looking forward to it. We first saw Springsteen live in July, 1978, at the San Antonio Municipal Auditorium (which seated just over 1,7O0 people). It was a fantastic show. 

My Facebook friend Edward Douglas is a film critic. Edward recently posted his review and said this movie was the best thing he had seen this year. That raised my hopes after some other things I‚Äôd read that were less positive.
The opening scene is Springsteen winding up a concert in 1981. I got a little misty-eyed at how well the filmmakers captured the excitement of one of Springsteen‚Äôs shows. The man has a fantastic stage presence. 

We didn‚Äôt realize until later that Jeremy Allen White did his own singing (and guitar playing), though while watching it, we thought he'd nailed Springsteen‚Äôs speaking voice. We‚Äôd only seen him on ‚ÄúShameless,‚Äù in which he plays a kid from a low-income family who gets into college. I was glad his performance wasn't Lip Gallagher with a Jersey accent.

[more to follow]
REEM crossing ROSAMUND is wild and I will freely use the word Natick to describe that intersection.

I was extraordinarily proud of getting DEMAGOGUERY for 24A right off the bat on the first across pass. 

Until I wasn't.

Some sticky corners in this puzzle but the down crossers really did loosen up some of the longer across entries making it a feasible solve. 

Until it wasn't. 'Coz SPINAFIB looked really good in the NE.

Happiness is not having to flyspeck a Sunday puzzle.
I was so intent on finishing the puzzle that I forgot to notice there wasn't a theme.  
So far it seems that I am one of the few who has heard of Ali LARTER. 
I had never heard of Daikin Park. Any relation to Linkin Park? Kidding. But fie on the ASTROS.  I'm so old that I still get confused because they switched leagues. 
I love MOSAICS and have seen a few Greek ones in my travels and always like to check them out in museums. And there are a few in the NYC subway system. 
And now I can't unsee the Donnie Darko rabbit.
I think I exhausted the ways to missspell Kamenski - imho Nadia and Simone are sporting names worth remembering. Loamy anyone?
Potter‚Äôs wheel not pottery wheel. Sometimes knowing the correct term trips you up.

Several things about this puzzle. Shocked that I didn‚Äôt get POTTERY WHEELS sooner as many friends and family are potters. My mom once had a job helping with the Giffin Grip. You know it if you‚Äôre into throwing. (Lol.;)). Also found MOSAICS and PRAYER MATS appropriate
How does "Open Faced" mean themeless?? I finished the whole puzzle frustrated that I never found anything alluding to faces!

Ho hum. Was the construction skillful? Absolutely. But this crossword was not for me. No real thrills, interest, or clever wording and a bit of a bummer to not get a theme. My lack of enjoyment definitely wasn‚Äôt helped by the hefty (imo) number of names required- over all it felt a bit bogged down. I think the content was sacrificed a bit for the sake of construction goals. But that‚Äôs just me- I am glad others liked it and I did, after all, do the whole thing so it can‚Äôt have been that bad!

As someone named Peter, I enjoyed this puzzle. 

Except for the clue associating my name with ‚Äúfizzling out.‚Äù Us Peters are persevering folk! No more besmirching of the name Peter!

Welp, I think the puzzle was great.  But would have been better if it wasn‚Äôt a holiday weekend.  I was really jonesing for a good creepy crawlie themed puzzle. 

Oh well. Can‚Äôt get every thing I want.

A pretty nifty Sunday puzzle, I‚Äôd say. I was thoroughly entertained, and I say this as someone who isn‚Äôt a huge fan of Sundays as a rule. There was an awful dearth of black squares (junky glue fill, where did you go?) which always fills me with such respect for the constructor. All the long entries were so much fun. 

I‚Äôm looking at the grid as I write this so as to say something intelligent about all the excellent entries in this puzzle, despite its being 6am Sunday morning, and on the heels of my husband‚Äôs just getting to bed after watching game 7, and Se√±or Gato‚Äôs hour-long insistence that I should have been throwing his cat toy for him this whole time (good grief and congrats to all the Jays fans, looking at you @SBK!). And I‚Äôm realizing that I didn‚Äôt just like this puzzle‚ÄîI loved it.  

And that‚Äôs as intelligent as my brain can do at this ungodly hour. 

Happy Daylight Savings Time to all who celebrate.

why may those of us with no access to the print paper not see mr shortzs print introductions?

This was possibly the weirdest solve in my well over 2 years of doing these puzzles.

There were very few gimmes. The clues were totally not on my wavelength. Many of the guesses I had made turned out to be wrong. And even though the grid was not heavy on trivia, I knew almost nothing of what little there was of it.

And yet...

I completed the puzzle without lookups, and quickly, too - the solve took me a tad under 40 minutes, which is quite fast for a Sunday that feels hard.

I almost broke down in the lower left (SW) corner - the only area with an accumulation of trivia entries, which also crossed. Even the non-trivia entry of PSA was clued "trivially" - why do constructors/editors do that? If a closed-off section of the puzzle already suffers from an overabundance of proper names, brands, etc., why not clue the other stuff there so that it does not require knowing trivia?

Anyway, I knew Smokey the Bear so I handled it. But it was close. As I was looking at that SW triangle of death, my finger hovered over the onscreen button that initiates an AI search of whatever it is that I mark. 

In the end I completed the puzzle without outside help. But did I enjoy the solve? Nah. I had to work too hard for this win to enjoy it. A regular-sized grid of this difficulty would have been fine. But. Sunday one... I found it too tiring.

But hey! At least there were no groaners!

Hey, puzzlers. Hope you all have food.

Great grid, Rafael, thanks. Started out stumped, but the path took shape and i only had to look up a few writers and a model. Particularly enjoyed the clue for the letter-shaped construction material.

Caitlin, as at least one other noted below, film stock hasn't been made from nitrate since the 1950s. Since then, it's mostly polyester. Tough and not very dangerous/flammable. In one little neighborhood repertory theater where i worked in the '80s, we were still using carbon arc lamps, which used to be standard in cinemas until the '60s. This arcane technology involved two pencil-like rods of carbon pointed at one another and kept by a motor in (theoretically) ideal proximity to maintain an actual flame between them, the light from which shone the film image onto the screen a hundred feet or so away. The motor of course did not work ideally, so the rods were prone to fusing (getting too close and hot, so film frames burned) or separating (getting too far apart, picture goes dark) if the projectionist wasn't constantly paying attention and jiggering the spacing with a little knob. From the '50s back, film projection (and spectating) was a death-defying act!

68D brought back memories.

I've been enchanted by Richard Feynman for a long time, and he became a scientific hero of mine when James Gleick's "Genius" came out.

A decade or so ago, I got a chance of a lifetime, at least for a community theater amateur--to play Feynman in the Peter Parnell play "QED".

Feynman was a genius in every sense of the word:  he invented new ways to do certain types of integrals, he self-taught himself  out how to pick combination locks, he did experiments with convoys of ants, he tried to train himself to keep perfect time, the tried to analyze what happens when he fell asleep.

And he developed a way of describing sub-atomic particle interactions that was brilliantly useful and intuitive (to people smarter than me).  Quantum Electro Dynamics.  QED.

He was curious about everything.  Everything.  How a rotating dinner plate wobbles.  How train wheels work.  How to tell what's in a food can without the label.  

He entertained kids by asking questions like "Do you know there are more numbers than there are numbers?"  As a lucky man, I've been able to ask my grandkids that question.

I was a quantum chemist in a happier time, and I often stumbled when asked the question "But what is it good for? Hmm?  Mr. College Boy?  What can yo do with it?"

Feynman courageously answered, "Physics is like sex: sure, it may give some practical results, but that's not why we do it."

A brilliant, flawed, wonderful, creative and, most of all, curious man.

OK, I've been (mostly) lurking for a few months, but after all the comments I'm seeing about the grid and a face, I'm compelled to ask:

Wha? Huh? Who? 

and most of all

Why? 

I never (as in never ever) look at the layout of the black squares in the grid, and just don't understand those who do. To me, it's like going to an art gallery to admire the frames around the paintings.

It's a CROSSWORD puzzle, not a GRIDART puzzle!

I raced through the NW and NE so quickly that I really thought I was on track for a Sunday PB ‚Äî just one of those kind meld situations! Unfortunately or fortunately, depending on your pension for crunchier solves, the center and W slowed me down considerable. What I thought might somehow be under 10 minutes wound up just shy of 25.

Anyway, a very solid construction! All killer, no filler.

all this fuss about themeless vs themed sundays.
sometimes i feel like a ripple drinker at a sommelier convention when i read the comments.
but to paraphrase duke ellington:  if it solves good, it is good.

New personal best for a Sunday :) 
41:42
3:21 faster than my average. 

Would have been a bit faster if I hadn't wasted so much time trying to figure out what I got wrong.  I almost "saw red" when I spotted it, but I only "saw ree" :(
About the "Ones skilled in governance" clue Mr. Musa...you could also fit POLICY WONKS in this answer, are you a Knowledge Fight listener by any chance?
I've heard of pianoforte but I never heard of fortepiano (but apparently that IS a thing). A filler-inner. Themeless Sunday puzzles are always a let-down. I'm sorry but they are.

I knew this puzzle and I were going to get along as soon as I saw the puppy dog face in the grid! Reminded me of my sweet Maxine who we said goodbye to around this time last year at 17 years and 5 months. I miss her everyday. 

This was definitely in my wheelhouse and brought to mind many things I love, in addition to Maxine.

My husband and I hiked all 5 Utah NPs in May, hitting most of the major trails. The Narrows at Zion is the one place where we hired guides and rented WADErS, which allowed us to make it to where you can‚Äôt go farther without a permit. Every one of the parks is stunning and should not be missed. Sad/angry for the staff who are not getting paid, the public who can‚Äôt enjoy these treasures and the local economies suffering during the shutdown. 

I practice yoga daily so ONELEG was a gimme. At the studio where I took ceramics we just called it the WHEEL, but POTTERYWHEEL also sounds right to me.  Cold SAKE is delicious but I favor ice cold beer with sushi. I lived and worked in SILICONVALLEY for 20  years, including San Francisco where Rafa lives and works, so maybe that‚Äôs why so much of this resonated with me (even though I am at least twice his age!). 

Lovely way to enjoy my coffee today. Thanks Rafa!

First of all, the grid reminded me of a bunny pumpkin I carved a few years ago, but Rafael did a better job in a less forgiving medium. In early week puzzles, I don't typically care about themes, but I always hope for a really devious, convoluted theme on a Sunday. It happens rarely, but when it does, it makes my day. Once I got over the disappointment that today was not going to be one of those days, I enjoyed my solve of this giant open grid. PSA: If you haven't made it yet, check out REEM Kassis' recipe, Narjissiya With Asparagus, Halloumi and Sumac https://cooking.nytimes.com/recipes/1021984-narjissiya-with-asparagus-halloumi-and-sumac?unlocked_article_code=1.yE8.83Nd.KKnC6ruEnSmA&smid=share-url It's really tasty with some pomegranate molasses a little za'atar. Not that it helped me get her name right off.

I enjoyed it.  I like a theme.  I like a themeless.  I like a rebus.  I like no rebus.  I like elegant.  I like corny.  Mainly, I like words.  I'm glad constructors are willing to puzzle us - seems like something of a thankless task.  I imagine it is a lot of work for not much glory.  If that makes me easy to please, then guilty as charged.  Since in life I am hard to please - just ask my family - it makes a nice break from reality.

For me, this is the Sunday of the year -- the beauty of the construction, the lack of virtually any standard fill, and cute grid art as well?  How you pulled this off Rafael is beyond me.

I often complain about Sundays -- so much standard small-ball fill to plow though makes them a slog for me.  The themes rarely amuse me.  I wish every Sunday puzzle was like Rafael's!

Generally fun solve of a well constructed puzzle.  But, I would take the comment from the Tricky Clues section on Reem/Rosamund a bit further, and apply it not to this puzzle alone.  The increasing trend of the use of obscure first names of various people garnered from searches rather than reasonable knowledge, just to complete a clever pattern, has replaced the old junk filler words that we now scorn in constructing. Bring back the adit, I say!

Difficult to enjoy a puzzle with so many proper nouns. 
Even without the use of obscure ones, every single proper is an admission of defeat by the constructor that they don‚Äôt know a dictionary word that they can make fit.
So, poor.
A themeless Sunday is a waste of everyone's time.

I remember reading that when he was tired, Mozart would often compose at a SOFA FORTE PIANO.

[This paragraph deleted by author, as it got carried away with SORE LOSER, SCARE TACTICs, FALSE IMPRESSIONs, SPIN A WEB, CULT HERO, BADDY, and HOOEY]

Adored this one. So many mini-themes and juicy entries. Enough friction to make it a battle, including trying to figure out the theme for the first half (two-thirds) of the puzzle.  Beautifully done, Rafael.

I'm one of the few who doesn't care for themes, I'm only really interested in clever clues. I didn't realise that Sundays usually have themes, I often solve without thinking about the theme and I like this crossword.

I was so pleased to solve the whole thing without looking up the several words and names that I didn't know, using crossers only. 

Is PONY KEG a term that is in everyday use? Do people buy quarter barrels of beer rather than bottles or cans? I looked it up and found an array of units for beer - firkin and hogshead I'd heard of, but not kilderkins.
Some day long in the future I will look back and wonder how I ever solved a Sunday in just under 17 minutes.  Then I‚Äôll remember it was just a big Tuesday.

I've now read all 217 of the previous comments. Yup, still up at 4:50 Pacific Time. Hate it on the nights the clocks change, and Oseem to get to bed even later. But I always must print and finish the puzzle before that can happen.

 I'm surprised that no one commented on SILICON VALLEY / TECHNOCRATS / THAT‚ÄôS RICH. Rafa says in his notes that it made him smile. I can't say the same for me. It conjures up the image of that tacky umbrella-clad spot that was the former Rose Garden, and the big, fancy party given for all the rich people yesterday, while so many of the peasants will go without food in order to pay their outrageous sky-high med insurance premiums. The gilded age, indeed. Very poor timing for those three clues all in one puzzle.

You know, I just thought of this, but the title and the grid layout look a lot like the face of a Dancing Bear (although Owsley says they're marching, as in a parade). See if you agree: https://cdn.wallpapersafari.com/47/30/768mAl.jpg Brought this in several minutes under my average, but it was daunting at first. Doing it online, with easy DELETIONs and corrections, sure helped. I had DEMAGOGUERY before SCARETACTIC and [something]JUDGE before NFLREFEREE. Never heard of SAEED, LARTER, ROSAMUND, REEM, or DELANEY, which meant I got a little surprise when I fixed one letter and got the gold star. Thanks for a fun challenge!
The names in the bottom left were the only tricky bit, otherwise a silky smooth Sunday

So do I *wear* the chickens, or can I better predict the weather by watching them? Trusting the layers are not harmed‚Ä¶



Back for another try: The disguise is too good - who‚Äôs the theme?
Boring, easy, 14:17 solve on a Sunday? C'mon

I really had to work at this one, and found the bottom left corner to be especially annoying due to the crossing of two obscure authors' names. But I'm proud of myself for getting it without googling anything.

Using an obscure ancient philosopher (Lao Tse) that has multiple variations of spelling their name, and not using one of the more common variants (wikipedia lists him as Laozi and Lao Tzu) is literally "HOOEY". Disagree.  They do get easy.  You've only been doing these for a year.  I've been doing them for over 40.

At some point, you get good enough to realize that for any given puzzle, it's not a question of if, but rather when, you'll finish.  That realization is game-changing.

Note that constructors generally put their tricky answers or unguessable names with gentle crosses.  That's why "Natick" became a phrase:  in that puzzle, NATICK crossed NC WYETH was uninferable, which was  exceedingly rare.  Today's REEM/ROSAMUND crossing approaches that, but if you can get PSU (Penn State University), ROSAMUND is inferable (as opposed to ROSALIND) as the only likely name.  

Understanding that the constructor is not going to cross a not-universally-known name like REEM with an uniferable name, let's say "Rosavend" or "Rosayind," helps you get through. 

Do these puzzles another year, and I guarantee you will be at a higher level, and perhaps able to manage Saturday puzzles.

A little late but here's my translation of Odi et Amo as a haiku:

Uneasy, I love
Unknowing, it pierces me
and I am destroyed

@Al

Beautiful. 

A couple of thoughts. 

Odi: I really like your interpreting rather than translating this as a feeling of unease. This is, in fact, my favorite part of your haiku. 

After I saw your post this morning, I pulled up the original lines of C. 85 and took the time to think about them in English, rather than in Latin‚Äîmediating lexically rather than conceptually. (Of course this made my wont literality of delving into the structure of the language reduce the poeticality of the poem‚Ä¶) Here goes. 

I see ‚Äòodi‚Äô here as ‚ÄòI find [you/her/him] odious,‚Äô not as I ‚Äòhate.‚Äô See, ‚Äòodi‚Äô is one of Latin‚Äôs defective perfects, meaning it has no present form. It literally means ‚ÄòI have hated‚Äô (perfect), but functions as a present in meaning. So, grammatically and semantically, it‚Äôs baked in as a state resulting from past emotion‚Äînot the flaring, active passion of anger implied in the English ‚ÄòI hate,‚Äô but rather a settled stance, a cool judgment. 

Catullus could have gone with something like:

Detestor et amo‚ÄîI abominate and I love.
Exsecror et amo‚ÄîI curse and I love. 

But he didn‚Äôt. Instead he is repelled, made uneasy. 

He does the same with ‚Äòfieri sentio.‚Äô He doesn‚Äôt say, ‚ÄòI feel it,‚Äô but ‚ÄòI feel it coming into being.‚Äô ‚ÄòFieri‚Äô is a very passive-reflective construction, almost Stoic in flavor‚Äîas if he‚Äôs observing the externality of the process of these emotions happening to him. 

  ‚Äî I‚Äôll continue below

Continued ‚Äî

Given that, I like how you present the feelings as piercing him, because it preserves that externality. And I see the elegance of your semantically tying it in with ‚Äòexcrucior.‚Äô

But‚Äîand this is a big one. Catullus doesn‚Äôt say ‚Äòcrucifigor‚Äô‚Äî‚ÄòI‚Äôm being nailed to the cross,‚Äô implying the piercing feeling in your haiku‚Äîbut ‚Äòcrucior‚Äô‚Äî‚ÄòI am suffering the pain as if on the cross/rack/torture device‚Äô (the ‚Äòex-‚Äò intensifies it). In my English rendering, the second line reads as, ‚ÄòI do not know, but I feel this coming about, and I bear the cross [of this feeling]. 

Remember that Catullus is writing in the 1st c. BCE. Being put up on the cross is a form of torture, but not the killing-the-Son-of-God, never-to-be-forgiven-and-rendered-in-art-and-the-written-word-with-varying-degrees-of-convincing-pathos-for-millennia-to-come kind of torture. Hence the usual translation of ‚ÄòI feel it happening and it torments me‚Äô translations. I like preserving the ‚Äòcrux‚Äô or ‚Äòcross‚Äô in my translation today, hence my rendering it it today as ‚ÄòI bear the cross.‚Äô
